qas.question: On what date did the Austrian army first cross the Inn River?
Where was Napoleon when he received news of an Austrian invasion?
When Napoleon reached Donauwörth, how much distance were the wings of the Grande Armée separated by?
What was the name of the plan Napoleon devised to cut off the Austrians during battle?
What was the name of the conflict where the French defeated Austrian forces and forced them to withdraw to Bohemia?

context: In the early morning of <a0_0>10 April<a0_0/>, leading elements of the Austrian army crossed the Inn River and invaded Bavaria. The early Austrian attack surprised the French; Napoleon himself was still in <a1_0>Paris<a1_0/> when he heard about the invasion. He arrived at Donauwörth on the 17th to find the Grande Armée in a dangerous position, with its two wings separated by <a2_0>75 miles (121 km)<a2_0/> and joined together by a thin cordon of Bavarian troops. Charles pressed the left wing of the French army and hurled his men towards the III Corps of Marshal Davout. In response, Napoleon came up with a plan to cut off the Austrians in the celebrated <a3_0>Landshut Maneuver<a3_0/>. He realigned the axis of his army and marched his soldiers towards the town of Eckmühl. The French scored a convincing win in the resulting <a4_0>Battle of Eckmühl<a4_0/>, forcing Charles to withdraw his forces over the Danube and into Bohemia. On 13 May, Vienna fell for the second time in four years, although the war continued since most of the Austrian army had survived the initial engagements in Southern Germany.
